column1: The First Battle of the Fords of Isen was the first of Battles of the Fords of Isen at the Fords of Isen
column2: and marked the beginning of the War of the Ring. On 25 February
column4: Saruman attacked the Rohirrim army under Théodred
column5: Grimbold and Elfhelm. Sarumans  main objective was to kill Théodred. After Théodred was slain Sarumans army withdrew.

column1: ==History==
===Prelude===
The chief obstacles to an easy conquest of Rohan by Saruman were Théodred and Éomer. They were devoted to the Théoden and were high in his affections
column2: as his only son and his sister-son. They did all that they could to thwart the influence that Gríma gained when the Kings health began to fail. It was Grímas policy to bring his chief opponents into discredit with Théoden. But the steadfast loyalty of Théodred and Éomer to their king even in his apparent dotage made it very difficult for Gríma to achieve this. Gríma therefore tried to play them one against the other in the mind of Théoden
column3: representing Éomer as ever eager to increase his authority. In this he achieved some success
column4: which bore fruit when Saruman at last succeeded in achieving the death of Théodred.

column1: ===Sarumans Strategy===
Saruman had given special orders that Théodred should at all costs be slain.
All his fiercest warriors were engaged in reckless assault upon Théodred and his guard
column2: disregarding other events in the battle
column3: which might otherwise have resulted in a much more damaging defeat for the Rohirrim. The river Isen came down swiftly from its sources above Isengard. In the flat land of the Gap of Rohan the river became deep and rapid and it could only be crossed at the Fords of Isen. Saruman had an advantage as he could send his troops down either side of the Isen and attack the fords
column4: if they were held against him
column5: from both sides. On the other hand
column6: Théodred might send his troops across the fords
column7: either to engage Sarumans troops or to defend the western bridge-head. But if they were worsted then they would have no retreat except back over the fords with the enemy at their heels
column8: and possibly also awaiting them on the eastern banks.

column1: === The Battle ===
Sarumans attack was not unforeseen
column2: but it came sooner than was expected. Théodreds scouts had warned him of a mustering of troops
column4: mainly on the west side of the Isen. He therefore manned the approaches
column6: to the fords with sturdy men from the Westfold. He also left three companies of  Rohirrim
column7: along with horse-herds and spare mounts
column8: on the east bank. Théodred himself passed over with the main strength of his cavalry: eight companies and a company of archers
column9: intending to overthrow Sarumans army before it was fully prepared. Saruman however had not revealed his true intentions nor the full strength of his forces.

column1: Some twenty miles north of the fords Théodred encountered the enemys vanguard and scattered it
column2: however when he attacked the main host he found that the enemy was in fact prepared for the assault
column3: behind trenches manned by pikemen. And Théodred in the leading Éored was brought to a stand and was almost surrounded. He was extricated by the onset of the companies coming up behind him.

column1: But when he looked eastward he was dismayed. Away east of the river he saw other forces now hasting towards the fords. He at once ordered a retreat. But retreat was often delayed
column2: when the rearguard under Grimbold was obliged to turn and drive back their pursuers.

column1: When they finally reached the fords the day was waning. Théodred set Grimbold in command of the garrison on the west bank
The rest of the riders and all the horses he at once sent across the river
column2: while he along with his company manned the eyot in the midst of the river
column3: to cover the retreat of Grimbold if he was driven back. This was barely done when Sarumans eastern forces came down with unexpected speed. The eastern force was much smaller than the western force
column4: but it was more dangerous. In its van were some Dunlendings horsemen and a pack of wolf-riders. Behind them came two battalions of Uruk-hai
column5: heavily armed and trained to move at great speed. The garrison of the east bank was swept away by the sudden attack and the riders who had just crossed the river were caught still in disarray
column6: and though they fought desperately they were driven from the fords with the Uruks in pursuit.

column1: As soon as the enemy gained control of the eastern end of the fords
column2: a company of men and orc-men appeared
column3: mail-clad and armed with axes. They assailed the eyot from both sides. At the same time Grimbold on the west bank was attacked by Sarumans forces on that side. When he looked eastward he was dismayed to see the axe-men driving Théodreds men from the shores of the eyot towards the low knoll in its centre. At once Grimbold
column4: taking a few men that stood near him ran back to the eyot. So fierce was his onset that he clove his way through the rear of the

column1: attackers
column2: till with two others he reached Théodred standing alone on the knoll.

column1: But he was too late. As he came to his side Théodred fell
column2: hewn down by a great orc-man. Grimbold slew the attacker and stood over the body of Théodred
column3: thinking him dead; and there he would himself soon have died
column4: but for the coming of Elfhelm.

column1: Elfhelm had been riding in haste from Edoras
column2: leading four companies in answer to Théodreds summons. When he reached the junction of the horse-road and the road down from the Deeping-coomb
column3: his outriders reported that two wolf-riders had been seen abroad on the fields. Sensing that something was amiss
column4: he did not turn aside to Helms Deep for the night as he had intended but rode with all speed towards the fords. And though his men and horses were weary
column5: as he came in sight of the east banks
column6: he ordered his companies to charge. It was the turn of the Isengarders to be surprised. Few stood their ground. Most fled northwards
column7: pursued by two of Elfhelms companies. The others he dismounted to guard the east bank
column8: but at once with the men of his own company rushed to the eyot. The axe-men were now caught between the surviving defenders and the onslaught of Elfhelm
column9: with both banks still held by the Rohirrim. They fought on
column10: but before long were slain to a man. Elfhelm himself
column11: however sprang up to the knoll and there he found Grimbold fighting two great axe-men for the possession of Théodreds body. One Elfhelm at once slew
column12: and the other fell before Grimbold.

column1: When they stooped to lift the body
column2: they found that Théodred still breathed; but he lived only long enough to speak his last words. Then a harsh horn sounded

column1: then all was silent. The attack on the west bank ceased and the enemy there faded away into the dark.
=== Aftermath ===
The Rohirrim held the Fords of Isen; but their losses were heavy
column4: and did not know what might yet befall. When the grey light of dawn returned
column5: there was no sign on the Isengarders
column6: except for those many that they left dead upon the field. Many men who had been scattered by the sudden assault began to return
column8: others leading recaptured horses. Later on in the morning
column9: most of Théodreds Riders that had been driven south down the river came back battle-worn but in good order. They had a similar tale to tell. They came to a stand on a low hill
column10: and prepared to defend it. Though it was now full night
column12: and soon they discovered that the enemy had gone. After some time they began cautiously to advance north again. But when they reached the Fords they were surprised to see the Rohirrim in command.
